rev.comment: /* National corporatism, national socialism and national syndicalism */ (See WP:REFB#Inserting a reference)
/* Economic policies */ contextual clarification for NPOV in comparison with communist states
/* Racism and racialism */ section separator to prevent confusion with preceding "core tenets"
deleted See Also section because it only had one link, which is already in the template anyway
unsourced claims do not belong -- please use Talk page. Thanks
/* Para-fascism and commonly alleged fascist ideologies */ making it clear that "fascism" in this article does not apply to them, simplifying
/* Racism and racialism * new head to break clearly from "core tenets"
/* Position in the political spectrum */ added p. no. to footnote
Because the definition of fascism is so variable this section is valid, and the groups described dont meet narrower defintions but do meet broader ones.
/* Para-fascism and commonly alleged fascist ideologies */ stuff which is "outside the range of fascism" is here why?
redundant; social democracy is a form of representative democracy
class conflict is not an ideology or political system
/* Position in the political spectrum */ grouping
/* Position in the political spectrum */ not a place to discuss Jung's views
/* Position in the political spectrum */ this section shouldn't rely on original quotes because they are easily misrepresented

moved content that was in the wrong place
Non-nationalist socialism and conservatism are what fascism appears to oppose

Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contributions/90.214.82.56|90.214.82.56]] to version by Drilnoth. False positive? [[User:ClueBot/FalsePositives|Report it]]. Thanks, [[User:ClueBot|ClueBot]]. (635768) (Bot)
General cleanup using [[WP:CHECKWIKI|Check Wikipedia]], [[User:Cameltrader/Advisor.js/Description|Advisor]], and [[WP:FORMATTER|Formatter]]. You can help!
/* Racism and racialism */ Added more quotes of Mussolini espousing racialism in the 1920s
/* Social welfare */ This should be moved to the economics section
Half a sentence is not straying off topic, and doesnt warrant a banner. If you dont like the line, edit it out.
Irrelevant opening sentence. This part about the definition of fascism, literally and on spectrum is too important to have such an obscure lead-in
Section on origins of Italian Fascism moved to that section as was previously out of place in sections dealing with fascism overall.
The neo-Nazis are modern fascists. This properly referenced quote is relevant. Was it removed just because you dont like it?
Facist as epthet relates to its word use, so should be under etymology
/* Racism and racialism */ Removed excess and unneeded sentences
/* Abortion, eugenics and euthanasia */ connection of neo-nazis to fascism in general is less than marginal
/* Racism and racialism */ making it clear that "racism" and "fascism" are not related per se
/* Position in the political spectrum */ add Wikilink
undid change that made the heading clear as mud
/* Position in the political spectrum */ refining to make clear that the entire bit about the spectrum is a pea soup fog at best
moved quote to a more appropriate section; it had nothing to do with etymology
cleaned up section headings and corrected some bad grammar/spelling
Fascism is used as a pejorative by people on the right as well, to claim only the left does so is POV, removed other material that is unecessary and could be seen as POV
representative democracy was what the fascists declared their official opposition to, alphabetized one list
/* Founding of Facism -- Italian Fascism */ Shortened down material, removed unsourced material
Tenets, core or otherwise of other systems is not relevant.
Reverse POV edits made without any discussion
/* Economic policies */ varies all over the map in fact
/* Abortion, eugenics and euthanasia */ Italy was before Germany, general statement precedes specific statements
/* Political spectrum */ deleted context-less off-topic content with no clear link to actual fascism. There was no conensus to add it.
It may be possible that the abortion section is more closely associated with Nazism than fascism, but I think its worth mentioning. Thats all this is, a mention.
material is coherent, was discussed and approved by consensus. Kindly do not alter sans consensus.
WikiProject Check Wikipedia: repaired curly brackets
/* Racism and racialism */ not a "core tenet" in any way
/* Culture and gender roles */ "anti-multi-culturalism" found in non-fascist states, not related to Fascism qua Fascism
/* Abortion, eugenics and euthanasia */ making it clear that abortion etc. are not "core tenets" of fascism at all
Date maintenance tags and general fixes
Did you even read that opening line? The common trait is that fascist states enforce these sorts of rules without regard to the individual, for which the evidence is substantial
/* Abortion, eugenics and euthanasia */ abortion etc. seems entirely dependent on each infdividual movement - not a general Fascist characteristic at all

/* Core tenets */ moved paragraph about economics from the Authoritarianism section to the Economics section
/* Authoritarianism */ copy edited and re-ordered paragraph
/* Social welfare */ I know this part is accurate, as I added it, but am not sure what the source is, until I find the source, it can't be in the article
/* Economic planning */ Removed a section that was talking about Nazism alone and was largely unreferenced
/* Economic planning */ No reference for this has been provided since asked for in January, so this sentence is being taken out
/* National corporatism, national socialism and national syndicalism */ Shortened section, removed unsourced material
/* Notable fascist leaders */ This section is irrelevant and in the past has been repeatedly filled by "supposide" fascist leaders, and insignificant fascist puppet state leaders
There are differences between the IRAA and generic fascism, the IRAA was more of a coalition of various fascist and nationalist movements and was not radical, as it was formed by the government
Second thought, I am changing it back to what it was earlier
"and/or" not necessary, "or" is the best term
Restored the sentence to what it was earlier which is like what the references describe
"Strong central leadership" is sugarcoating the fact that fascist governments were literally led by dictators

The intro had a very vague section about fascism aiming to solve "social, economic and political problems", every serious political movement does so, so that is not unique

'spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk" uses "freepedia" which is not RS -- in fact it uses WP as its source
/* Notable fascist leaders */ Due to the strong fusion of religious concepts into the Romanian Iron Guard, Codreanu is significant
/* Notable fascist leaders */ Ikki Kita was a more unique influence on fascism in Japan than Seigo Nakano
/* Notable fascist leaders */ Nope, Dimitrije Ljotic is not an important fascist, he is not unique, and now that I think of it neither is Gombos

/* Falangism (Spain) */ sticking to fascism as much as possible

Combined Falangism & Francoism - per Collect's request
/* Para-fascism and commonly alleged fascist ideologies */ The Taisei Yokusankai was definately fascist, it is not alleged
/* Variations and subforms */ The Taisei Yokusankai was definately a fascist political party, it was nationalist, totalitarian, and adopted fascist-like groups including paramilitary organizations

fully sourced material can not be termed "gibberish"
/* Political spectrum */ added "Clarify" tag to two sentences that need clarification about what they have to do with actual fascists, instead of socialists with some fascist-like characteristics
KKK not fascist except as epithet
/* Political spectrum */ Added text for Linehan reference

One source for phrase, many for EACH term - hence correct and a summary of the paragraph as well. Thanks! see Talk on this
/* Political spectrum */ ipsett seems to be the sole source for this
/* Social welfare */ copy edited for grammar, syntax, etc.
/* Religion */ Delete assertions which have been unsourced and tagged and aren't fascist.

Obedience is a major factor in fascism and a reason why fascists did not support egalitarianism, because it inherently means giving rights to people who may be disobedient
Fascists are not interested in representing or promoting a single social class, they are class collaborationists who declare that they oppose any form of hostility from one class to another.
